page.title: 11Ecology of Braydon 1
page.content: This section is largely a mixture of open farmland and woodland with a small lake and a small area of housing development. This provides a diversity of wildlife habitats - badgers, foxes, deer, rabbits, hares and a variety of small mammals, birds and reptiles live here. The badger is under threat as it is thought to be the cause of bovine tuberculosis in cattle and its numbers are dwindling. The foxes are hunted by hounds and the hares by beagles but neither are in immediate danger. There is also duck shooting on the lake. There are Roe and Muntjac deer to be found in some of the woodland, these have escaped from nearby parks and have wandered into the area. The woodland here is the remnant of a much larger forest which once stretched from Cricklade to Malmsbury.
